title: Why is desalination so difficult?
dot:
digraph Desalination{rankdir=LR;node[shape=box];Carlsbad_Plant[label="Carlsbad Desalination Plant
San Diego, California
Produces 10% of local fresh water
(50 million gallons/day)"];Desalination[label="Desalination
Removal of salt from seawater"];Global_Plants[label="18,000 Desalination Plants
< 1% of global water needs
Consumes 25% of water industry energy"];Methods[label="Desalination Methods
1. Distillation
2. Reverse Osmosis"];Distillation[label="Distillation
- Heat to vaporize water
- Condense vapor to collect fresh water
- Inefficient for large scale"];RO[label="Reverse Osmosis
- Uses high pressure to push seawater through membranes
- More efficient than distillation"];Salinity[label="Salinity
- Seawater: ~35g salt/L
- Drinking water limit: 1g salt/L"];Energy_Costs[label="Energy Costs
- High energy requirement for both methods
- Desalination can be costly"];Environmental_Impact[label="Environmental Impact
- Brine disposal issues
- Potential harm to marine life"];Alternatives[label="Alternatives to Desalination
- Rainwater harvesting
- Groundwater
- Brackish water treatment"];Future[label="Future of Desalination
- Increasing viability in arid regions
- Private sector involvement
- Potential for renewable energy use"];Carlsbad_Plant->Desalination;Desalination->Global_Plants;Desalination->Methods;Methods->Distillation;Methods->RO;RO->Energy_Costs;Distillation->Energy_Costs;Desalination->Salinity;Desalination->Environmental_Impact;Desalination->Alternatives;Desalination->Future;edge[color=blue];node[style=filled, fillcolor=lightyellow];}
